title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
#Entries represent injuries sustained per 10,000 competitions in the named sport
football <- c(34,21,3,5,11,7,18,3,19)
hockey <- c(18,13,2,2,5,8,3,1,5)
wrestling <- c(14,7,4,2,2,1,7,1,3)
lacrosse <- c(11,3,1,2,4,3,9,1,4)
soccer <- c(11,1,1,2,2,5,5,2,6)
basketball <- c(7,1,1,2,4,2,3,1,13)

mat <- cbind (football, hockey, wrestling, lacrosse, soccer, basketball)
injury <- c("Head","Shoulder","Arm","Trunk","Hand","Thigh","Knee","Lower Leg","Ankle")
sport <- c("Football","Hockey","Wrestling","Lacrosse","Soccer","Basketball")
colnames(mat) <- sport
rownames(mat) <- injury
mat

          Football Hockey Wrestling Lacrosse Soccer Basketball
Head            34     18        14       11     11          7
Shoulder        21     13         7        3      1          1
Arm              3      2         4        1      1          1
Trunk            5      2         2        2      2          2
Hand            11      5         2        4      2          4
Thigh            7      8         1        3      5          2
Knee            18      3         7        9      5          3
Lower Leg        3      1         1        1      2          1
Ankle           19      5         3        4      6         13






#Creating data frame and adding body location as a variable
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

inj.sport <- as.data.frame(mat)
body <-rownames(inj.sport)
inj.sport$Injuries = factor(body, ordered = T, levels = rev(body))
inj.sport

          Football Hockey Wrestling Lacrosse Soccer Basketball  Injuries
Head            34     18        14       11     11          7      Head
Shoulder        21     13         7        3      1          1  Shoulder
Arm              3      2         4        1      1          1       Arm
Trunk            5      2         2        2      2          2     Trunk
Hand            11      5         2        4      2          4      Hand
Thigh            7      8         1        3      5          2     Thigh
Knee            18      3         7        9      5          3      Knee
Lower Leg        3      1         1        1      2          1 Lower Leg
Ankle           19      5         3        4      6         13     Ankle

rownames(inj.sport) = NULL





#long pivot / gather data
inj.sport.long <- gather(inj.sport,key = Sport, value = Number, Football:Basketball, factor_key = T)





#Subset head injuries
subset_head <-subset(inj.sport.long, Injuries == "Head")
subset_head

   Injuries      Sport Number
1      Head   Football     34
10     Head     Hockey     18
19     Head  Wrestling     14
28     Head   Lacrosse     11
37     Head     Soccer     11
46     Head Basketball      7

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
#Entries represent injuries sustained per 10,000 competitions in the named sport
football <- c(34,21,3,5,11,7,18,3,19)
hockey <- c(18,13,2,2,5,8,3,1,5)
wrestling <- c(14,7,4,2,2,1,7,1,3)
lacrosse <- c(11,3,1,2,4,3,9,1,4)
soccer <- c(11,1,1,2,2,5,5,2,6)
basketball <- c(7,1,1,2,4,2,3,1,13)

mat <- cbind (football, hockey, wrestling, lacrosse, soccer, basketball)
injury <- c("Head","Shoulder","Arm","Trunk","Hand","Thigh","Knee","Lower Leg","Ankle")
sport <- c("Football","Hockey","Wrestling","Lacrosse","Soccer","Basketball")
colnames(mat) <- sport
rownames(mat) <- injury
mat

          Football Hockey Wrestling Lacrosse Soccer Basketball
Head            34     18        14       11     11          7
Shoulder        21     13         7        3      1          1
Arm              3      2         4        1      1          1
Trunk            5      2         2        2      2          2
Hand            11      5         2        4      2          4
Thigh            7      8         1        3      5          2
Knee            18      3         7        9      5          3
Lower Leg        3      1         1        1      2          1
Ankle           19      5         3        4      6         13

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
#Creating data frame and adding body location as a variable
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

inj.sport <- as.data.frame(mat)
body <-rownames(inj.sport)
inj.sport$Injuries = factor(body, ordered = T, levels = rev(body))
inj.sport

          Football Hockey Wrestling Lacrosse Soccer Basketball  Injuries
Head            34     18        14       11     11          7      Head
Shoulder        21     13         7        3      1          1  Shoulder
Arm              3      2         4        1      1          1       Arm
Trunk            5      2         2        2      2          2     Trunk
Hand            11      5         2        4      2          4      Hand
Thigh            7      8         1        3      5          2     Thigh
Knee            18      3         7        9      5          3      Knee
Lower Leg        3      1         1        1      2          1 Lower Leg
Ankle           19      5         3        4      6         13     Ankle

rownames(inj.sport) = NULL

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
#long pivot / gather data
inj.sport.long <- gather(inj.sport,key = Sport, value = Number, Football:Basketball, factor_key = T)

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
#Subset head injuries
subset_head <-subset(inj.sport.long, Injuries == "Head")
subset_head

   Injuries      Sport Number
1      Head   Football     34
10     Head     Hockey     18
19     Head  Wrestling     14
28     Head   Lacrosse     11
37     Head     Soccer     11
46     Head Basketball      7

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
Stacked Bar

ggplot(inj.sport.long, aes(x=Sport, y = Number, fill = Injuries))+geom_col()+
  labs(y="Injuries per 10,000 Competition Plays", title = "High School Sports Injuries", fill = "Injury Type")+
  theme_minimal()

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
Line Plot

##Line Plot
ggplot(inj.sport.long, aes(x= Injuries,y=Number,fill = Sport,group = Sport)) +
  geom_point(shape = 21, size = 2.8) + 
  geom_line(aes(color = Sport)) +
  labs(y = "Injuries per 10,000 Competition Plays",x="Type of Injury",title = "High School Sports Injuries", fill= "Sport")+
  theme_minimal()

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
Facet Wrap

ggplot(inj.sport.long, aes(x= Injuries,y=Number,fill = Sport,group = Sport)) +
  geom_point(shape = 21, size = 2.8) + 
  geom_line(aes(color = Sport)) +
  labs(x = "Injuries per 10,000 Competition Plays",y="",title = "High School Sports Injuries")+
  facet_wrap(~Sport)+ scale_y_continuous(breaks=seq(0,50,by =10)) + 
  theme(legend.position ="none")+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90))+
  theme_minimal()

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
Facet Grid

ggplot(inj.sport.long, aes(x= Injuries,y=Number,fill = Sport,group = Sport)) +
  geom_point(shape = 21, size = 2.8) + 
  geom_line(aes(color = Sport)) +
  labs(x = "Injuries per 10,000 Competition Plays",y="",title = "High School Sports Injuries")+
  facet_grid(~Sport)+ scale_y_continuous(breaks=seq(0,50,by =10)) + 
  theme(legend.position ="none")+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90))+
  theme_minimal()

title: R Code: New York Times High School Sports
text:
Head Injuries

ggplot(subset_head,aes(x=Sport, y=Number))+
  geom_col(aes(fill = Sport))+
  geom_text(aes(label = Number),vjust = -0.5)+
  labs(title = "Head Injuries by Sport",y = "Number of Injuries per 10,000 Competition Plays", x="")+
  theme_minimal()

title: Group 3 Mid Project
text:
STAT 515 Section 001
Cory Trainor and Lana Hashem



Cory Trainor

title: About
text:
STAT 515 Section 001
Cory Trainor and Lana Hashem



Cory Trainor

title: New York Times: High School Sports Injuries
text:
In 2019 the New York Times published an article titled “Inside Football’s Campaign to Save the Game.” The article examined the sport’s culture and focused on the growing number of injuries among young players and the long term effects of these injuries. You can read the full article here.
Pictured below is one of the figures used to compare the number of injuries sustained by high school boys in six popular sports: football, hockey, wrestling, lacrosse, soccer, and basketball.





The figure offers an interesting comparison of the relative number of injuries, but without reading the numbers it is difficult to quickly compare the sports.



First, we compared the total number of injuries sustained during competition in each sport. The numbers of injuries are reported as injuries per 10,000 competition plays.









As you can see in the above graphic, the total number of recorded football injuries was over twice the number of any other sport in the surveyed population.



Next, let’s take a look at the number of injuries sustained by type, or by what body part was injured.









Football leads nearly all of the injury categories in the surveyed population. The figure below allows you to more easily compare the injury categories by sport.












The statistic that is most troubling to researchers and parents alike is the significant number of head injuries sustained by high school boys playing football. Head injuries are particularly dangerous for developing brains and, increasingly, head injuries have been linked to mental illness in teenage boys.
